transcript.content: That was the Travis and some flowers through my window.
This is Xfm 104.9 of a Saturday afternoon, just gone six minutes past one, I'm Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant. Hi.
Hello there, hi good to talk to you.
Rick I just think, you know, we wanna lift off the show straight away.
And erm the best way to do that, it seemed to me, is to resurrect a game we used to play when we first began the show in old XFM days .
Do you remember the game, do you remember the game "Make Ricky Gervais..."
No, that was only in the pilot, we never actually did that live on air.
Um no it was the game "Make Ricky Gervais Laugh".
And we used to get people err, Karl you probably didn’t hear it, we used to get people to sort of send in pictures and jokes and stuff. And if I could make Ricky laugh on air with those.
Then they won a gift of some kind.
Anyway erm a lot of emails actually saying people love your laugh Rick, so in a sense were giving people what they want.
They must be taking the mickey.
But this is a picture I found in today’s copy of the sun, so if err you're listening at home and you wanna know what the picture looks like rush out and buy a copy only 40p.
Are we sponsored by The Sun, we do White Van Man.
It amused me straight away this, because bear in mind,
It is one of the worlds biggest rock stars.
Oh that is Michael Stipe oh dear with sort of glasses... looking like I dunno some sort of Nazi officer.
That’s not libelous, in your opinion Michael Stipe.
He’s outside there during the press conference for Peter Buck's...
It’s not a good picture. I love I think I love REM and I love Michael Stipe. I think he’s a lovely man, but that’s a bad picture isn’t it.
He’s got big glasses on and stubble and obvious … he doesn’t appear to be looking at anything. He’s looking right beyond everyone else.
I'll tell you who he looks like, he looks like Zig I think from Zig and Zag.
He looks like he is a muppet….
Nice to see that game come back.
Oh what a good picture that is, I hope you enjoyed it. Coming up soon we’ve got Sir David of Bowie.
Nicholas cave, err and Travis, Flowers in the Window again.
Really, like they left a sequencer going for a little while.
Yeh I don’t wanna diss the funny little French lads.
Do you speak much French Rick?.
I can ask where is the tourist information bureau, and erm I like, I can express my preference in music taste, and I can order an Orangina, and that’s all I can do.
I know un bière, blonde, pression, I think that means erm draught, you French.
That’s filthy. Do you know what that means Karl?
Do you know much French, Karl?
Erm, have you got any fromage?
Would you not care which one you were given? You like both.
That’s a whole different kettle of poisson.
I just think when you’re in, in a country you should have a little go.
Yeh you mean like football hooligans have a little go, what do you mean?
You know try and have a go at their err.
Well what I do is I go in there and I point and talk a bit louder than usual, in perfect English.
And if they don’t get it, I go mental.
Secure in the fact that I’ve tried my best and they’re having a laugh.
And that is the prerogative of all Englishmen.
Yeh. Point and shout, don’t forget you know because you can never be foreign if your English anywhere, no.  They’re speaking funny. Just remember that, yeh.
Steve begins to sing the British National Anthem
Sorry go on then you were going to say something else.
Yeh erm that picture you were showing me was I wish we could post one on the website of Karl you know when we won that we won an award ages ago, what was it called? The British Radio Authority award.
And erm we made Karl get in the picture, and he was a bit (inaudible) and everything but it came out nice, but his head is perfectly circular.
I put a coin on it, and it and only the ears popped out from behind the coin, isn’t it perfectly round, isn’t it?
I mean when you’ve been saying I’ve got a round head, I was a bit like “Yeh everyone has, stop having a go."
And then I saw this picture last week, I thought “God he’s right."
Can’t we just pop it on the Xfm website?
Steve have you seen that man in a jar without a brain?
Sorry you’ll... is that something… is that a product you can buy?
Is it a dream you had yesterday?
“Yes hello, erm could you make my dream into reality please?’ “We can’t actually sir.” “In err plastic would be good.”
In the future you’ll be able to download your dreams and then just like act them out again probably in the year 2000 or summit.
That’s got this little fella, who was born without a brain, and he’s in a jar and it’s just that he’s got a really round head.
And when I saw this picture I thought, god it just reminded me of this little fella in a jar.
Hold on what do you mean he’s born without a brain.
He was born without a brain.
Do you know the difference, do you have conversations with like people in prams thinking, That fella’s little and he doesn’t talk much!
You know babies aren’t like little people?
Well they are little people but I mean they’re not, they’re not very small adults. They’re not like midgets.
They don’t do a job of work is what Ricky’s saying.
I didn’t read about it I just saw the picture and…
This is where you’re going wrong Karl, this is always your mistake, you see the picture, you don’t read the little caption underneath.
But what do you mean how…
You guess at what you think the meaning is.
But how do you know he didn’t have a brain?
It said something like The Brainless Man.
Yeh but most people say that about you. It doesn’t mean literally you haven’t got a spinal...
No no. I bet somebody’s seen it and knows what I mean, it’s a famous picture.
Right call in, 08700 800 1234, once again, you win a prize if you can tell us what Karl is talking about.
Just in general, it’s an on going competition.
We’ll try and find some CDs for anyone who knows what Karl is talking about.
Stereophonics Vegas Two Times, well we've had calls confirming that there was indeed a um faetus or, or a stillborn child.
A pickled baby, no wonder it died, born without a brain erm but everyone has um you know pointed out it wasn't a little fella.
It certainly wasn't a little fella.
Yeah but because it had been in the jar for a long time I think it had aged a bit.
What are you basing that on?
You do carry on growing, yeah.
Your ears and your nose and your eyes don't grow so er.
I'll dig it out for you.
Imagine if, if like there was an experiment where they were raising a child just based on the information that we said on the radio.
What kind of a person would they be?
It was like download, yeah, yeah, yeah.
What kind of information would they have?
Nothing,yeah there was there was no irony or yeah, it was just.
It was just everything we said it assumed was fact, everything Karl said they assumed was factual.
And any question, any question it had about the world it could just ask Karl.

Now you see this worries me without wishing to be disrespectful in any way, you know I think you're the best man on earth, when you have a child we could be in a situation a bit like that.  Is it a concern for you do you think when your son is growing or your daughter and there askin' you questions, you're conscious, I mean you yourself have admitted.
You  have a sphere of knowledge which you are an expert on.
And I'd play with it, I think I'd be a good dad.
But I wouldn't be the one shouting at it.
No, who would you get to shout at it probably Windsor Davis, he'd be good wouldn't he. "You horrible little man".
You know I'd tell it the rights and wrong, you don't have to be a really bright person to know rights and wrong in the world.
No, I think you are bright Karl.
You are, and at what point in their um in their life would you tell them the about evolution of the baguette? Which you told us the other week.
Or the story of the bee.
Or the two children, would you ever get them to meet, as maybe I dunno they could be god-parents, the friends you had at school.
The big heads and the webbed hands.
I wish we could track them down.
I imagine they're in a zoo or something.
Or two big jars, industrial strength jars.
This is one of our last shows, were going away I’m afraid on the erm fourth of May isn’t it.
That’s our last show the fourth of May erm.
I brought a downer on the whole thing then didn’t I.
There’s people cheering away. Guess who’s taking over from us. And I found this out, I was watching Liquid News the other night.
No one had called me… Zoë Ball.
Well she’s a good presenter but is this confirmed?
I don’t know, should I have said that?
Err, yeh I think it’s alright, well yeh you’ve done it now. She was in the other day you watched it on the telly so.

But what annoys me is, this is rather like when we got, according to last weeks Media Guardian, we got rapped for err saying the word ‘cock’ on the radio, and erm we never did did we? that was, we had to read that on the internet, no one ever told us.
That just slipped out of your mouth didn’t it?
And erm now we don’t even get told face to face that Zoë Ball’s gunna take over.
Yeh but it was only like sorted out the other day, and when I saw you the other day.
We’re allowed to say 'ball' aren’t we?
Yeh when I saw you yesterday, I said yeh it’s... .
So were not allowed to say.

No I. No I'm not going to say the word, were not going to say, were not allowed to say the, we are allowed to say the male bird is a ‘cock.’ But were not allowed to say the other one, but we are allowed to say ‘ball’.
What if her and her dad, Bobby, would they be, would we be allowed to say they’re ‘a pair of balls.’ We’d be allowed to say that, I don’t know.
I don’t think he's part of the deal.
In fact if she’s listening call in and confirm it, we’ll let her on the air won’t we. As long as she doesn’t swear.
Better warn her as well not to leave too much, nothing lying around, cos it will be gone. Especially if its skag.
Echo and the Bunny Men, Killing Moon. Good to hear that again.
I’m Ricky Gervais, who are you?
Who’s that funny little round headed fella over there?
Well she hasn’t called, so it musn’t be true.
I hope she didn’t think we were, um, being disrespectful to her, because we both think she’s a fine presenter and I think she’ll do very well on here, I think it’s a good move as well.
Yeah but can you just say that it’s not, not forever?
I think she’ll, I think she’ll become more popular than us. Well she can...
And I think, I think, I think that will be the end of us to be honest.
Well she can string a sentence together.
Think she’ll get lots of PR out of it. And she goes out with big boy Slim.
He’s a good DJ. And ah, is her name “Zoe Slim” now?
Right, um, and ah you know, we’ll be nothing.
It’s three months innit she’s taking over for? Is she getting paid the same as us?
I bet it’s a hell of a lot more.
I bet it’s good money. It’s good work.
Well, there you go, what are you going to do?
I, I’m going to have Saturdays off.
What are you going to do?
Are you going to present with her? Are you going to come on and press the buttons?
No, I do, I hope no ah ‘cause you’re our...
Yeah. You’re like our little fella in a jar.
In fact that’s what we should do with you over the next, ah, three months.
Keep you in a jar and then we can have it in a-alternate weeks, like um like step parents or whatever.
Yeah, yeah. That would be great wouldn’t it?
Brilliant just you can be in a jar.
Or me and Steve can fight for custody.
Yeah. It’ll be a big jar though you can, you can put stuff in there.
You can, yeah you can have, it won’t be, it won’t be like um full of water, or, or vinegar or whatever they do or formaldehyde.
No. It’ll be, it’ll be like an air, a big air chamber and you’re sat, sat there and it’d be like a little. What would it be like, in an armchair or summat?
He’d be in an armchair and we’d, and we’d have stuff in there and we’d bring your girlfriend like once a week and she’d go, no we’d put a blanket over the top so we wouldn’t, you know, see anything.
But like the Big Brother household.
Now that’s a hell of a documentary.
Oh! That’d be amazing wouldn’t it?
But anyway that’s what, so we’re going away on the fourth of May for 12 weeks.
It’s a long time isn’t it?
We, we’re doing the second series of The Office so we can’t be around I’m afraid. And, and, ah, Zoe Ball’s standing in for us. And, ah...
That can’t be right, she’s not, I don’t think you can say “standing in for us”.
Taking over the show, I think would be fairer to say.
I don’t know. I’ve got, I can’t say anything now can ya? I’m worried about that. Just because she goes out with big boy Slim.
You gotta be careful what you say.
He’s starting thinking he’ll be getting melancholy now that you’re just gonna sit at home. What you gonna do every Saturday?
Let’s sort out a jar. ‘cause we gotta do the balloons before then as well, we gotta send you up in a balloon. Maybe, send you up in a balloon and you come straight down into a big jar.
And then put a, like a...
And we’ll put a giant cork in straight away.
Yeah, yeah, and there’s a big chair.
I’ll tell you what we could do, we could set you adrift like Robinson Crusoe sent a  bottle and see where you end up.
“If you find me”, yeah you might end up on an uninhabited island or summat.
I’ll tell you something that I learnt in the week.
That you just reminded me there, about going up in the air.
Right, if cars could drive up...
it’d only take an hour to get into space.
You just made that up didn’t ya?
You just plucked that out didn’t ya? You just plucked, you just guessed that. You just guessed that, you just said “about 50.”
See well, this is what worries me. If you have a, if you have a son or a daughter.
He’s going to be out in the street with a ramp, pointing into the sky.
“Dad, dad how long do elephants live?”
“Dad how much can an ant lift?”
“’bout a, ‘bout a quarter of a kilogram. Probably.”
If you guess, it’s not fact.
Yeah, it, just ‘cause you’ve thought it, that doesn’t make it fact. Does anyone know how long it would take a car going 50 miles an hour...
...people are phoning in about anything now Rick.
We asked them to phone in about the jar thing...
switchboard lit up! It’s crazy. You know you ask them to phone in about something sensible...
I love the fact that that...
...that is really a demographic sort of snapshot
Ask ‘em about a dead baby without a brain...
Oh yeah, straight on the phone.
...and they were reaching for the phones they don’t mind what their bill is that month.
Yeah, we ask them for a, you know, I don’t know, great quotes or something...
They’re just looking at the phone.
You know, you ask them where you can buy, you know, meths cheap...
You know the quotes that Ricky gave me last week and I turned them down?
I got home; girlfriend had a go at me.
They don’t know that you turned ‘em down. What you know is that...
...he said he didn’t want to take the book at the end of the show he said “I’m not takin’ it it’s too difficult, I’m gonna go get a nice one”. And, go on, carry on.

Yeah so I went home and, ah, Suzanne said “Where’s the book?” She was really looking forward to having a look at it. I said “oh, I gave it him back”. I wasn’t up for that, and yet last week I was ill and stuff, I wasn’t in the mood for learning.
I wasn’t having any of it. She goes “this is where you went wrong at school”.
She that “this is exactly where you went wrong”. She said “you know, you liked infants.”
“you liked, ah, you know, your colouring in and painting stuff”; said “but soon as it gets to the heavy stuff you just, you know, you’re like a horse with its blinkers on”.
She said “You just shut yourself away”. So I said, “No, I could have done if I wanted to”. So anyway, um, we went a bought a quotations book so I have got some quotes for today.
Yeah what’s the quotation book you bought? So I was asking him to ah read Keats and Wilde, Wordsworth, Shakespeare and tha’; what did you buy?
It’s, it’s, quotes with like Eric and Ernie and that innit?
The Sesame Street book of quotes? Brilliant.
No that’s, that’s still valid, no, it’s a starting point.
Well, we’ll have some of that after the...
Well we’ve got a lot more to get though before we get to those quotes.
Got a bit o’ New Order.

New Order, Here to Stay. On Xfm 104.9. Someone, I, I love our listeners, I really do, right. Ah, someone just called in and said “It’s about putting”, he went “hello”, Karl answers the phones, bloke said “hello”, he went “hello” and said “yeah about putting Karl in a big jar”, and Karl went “...go on”.
And the bloke went “well then you could call him Karl Pickleton” and he went “thanks”.

I love them bothering, I love Karl Pickleton, that’s lovely, that’s so sweet. He spent 50p to tell you that and you were worried, you just saw you going up in a balloon and landing in a jar again, didn’t ya’?

What have you gone through yet? You’ve had nothing but good feedback from this show now and now you’re just getting all worried aren’t ya? Heat magazine say you’re a genius, you got your picture in that extracts magazine with a little round head, you have jaffa cakes, I gave him a fiver the other week to buy biscuits. He’s having the time of his life, it’s the best day, ah, this must be your best two hours of the week.
Yeah? What’s a, what’s better regular than this for you? What’s a better two hours a week?
Um. Actually you’re probably right, it might be this.
Yeah, well that goes without saying doesn’t it?
He’s pulled it ‘round. He’s pulled it ‘round, he’s a charmer.
If she could come in and sit in the corner, then yeah, it would be the best time ever.
And she’s not even in London at the moment.
Oh well say what you want then.
So I didn’t have to say that.
You didn’t have to say it and you did anyway.
She, she might be listening somewhere.
Yeah, Sky Digital innit? There’s always that. There’s...
Yeah, anyway Steve, over to you.
Well I um, I just, well sorry, ‘cause obviously I, I’ve had an exciting week relatively speaking Rick.
‘cause instead of just spending it all with you.
I’ve been doing some acting this week as you know.

And, ah, I don’t normally act ah but I um, basically there are some people at the BBC who are making a, ah, comedy pilot, kinda comedy TV show and uh, you know and I auditioned for it and the role was to play a, ah, sort of freaky looking, sort of lanky geek. You know and ah, I don’t wanna sound...
How did you, how did you beat off all the...
I don’t want, I don’t want to sound arrogant Rick, but they gave the me the job on the spot.
You know, so it was like, you know, ah, obviously ah you know, ‘cause I’m not a bad actor, I’m not as good as Rick, but I’m, you know but I’m...
What was the, what was is ah, uh...?
It’s a, it’s a, I play a very tall guy, like a sort of...
That’s the part ah, that’s the part though isn’t it? About you got a beard?
I’m a character who’s, ah six foot seven inches tall and I’m trying to win the world’s, ah, tallest man competition.
That’s it, that’s it, yeah, yeah.
But, ah, there’s always a man that beats me every year ‘cause he’s slightly taller, but this year I think for some reason, because I’ve been training that I can beat ‘im.

And um, yeah, Sally Phillips, I don’t know if you know Sally Phillips, she, she’s a very good, ah, writer and comedy actress and she’s written it. And so it was good fun and I went down there and it was good and everything and I had a little trailer and everything, it was like the proper deal, it was really good and, um, the problem was that yesterday I had to dance. One of the sequences has me dance. Now as you know that I think I’m a pretty groovy dancer.
I’m pretty, I’m a bit of a mover.
And, I have to tell you this Rick.
Did you have anyone’s eye out with your elbow?
I have come to some pretty serious realisations about my dancing.
I was moving ‘round like a shire horse dancing.
It was terrible, I was just like creaking, ‘cause they had this choreographer that was trying to show me some moves and it was just like...
‘cause he, he was just like crying near the end of it.

It was so bad but the worst thing about it is… today, my whole body is ravaged with pain and agony, it’s—I’m utterly devastated by the, the agony of it. Tried to get down the stairs this morning, I swear to God, I looked like Thora Hird.

Trying to hobble down—it was mad. I was like I’d had several hip replacements. I was like—I had to go down at an angle, going down the stairs, and it was ludicrous, I was really worried, suddenly I’m thinking—‘cause I thought was pretty fit and…

And I had been discussing with uhm this mate of mine, my housemate, that we should maybe do—start doing some exercise, because I’m putting on a little bit of weight, right, he’s quite a thin tall guy, he has a belly… I don’t know how to summarize it, have you ever seen the film “Junior” with Arnold Schwarzenegger?

It’s slightly grotesque, so the two of us were—so we suggested, we decided that we were gonna do some exercise together, right, this is what we’re gonna do, each morning we were gonna get up, we’re gonna exercise together…

…right—well, no, but wait, Rick. You see, you’re wrong because… a couple of days ago I said to him, listen, what we should do is get one of those, like, health videos, you know, those kind of training videos, what are they called, like uhm… I don’t know, they might have an aerobics thing or…
…a sort of hour-long workout. And I said to him, get one of the ones that’s hosted by like uhm…

…Elle Macpherson or Cindy Crawford, you know, you know, someone like that, someone sexy, right? So I swear to God, we went down this morning, we put it on, right? Just want you to picture this scene, right? It’s me, and my mate, in our shorts, right, 9 o’clock in the morning, working out…
…right? That was—“It was the cheapest one, Steve,” he told me. Thanks very much, mate.
We saw that advertised as well.

Yeah. Workin’ out, right, and the two of us in our shorts, she’s there like—you know, she’s the closest there is to a living Homer Simpson, right, shoutin’ out and stuff… I just wanted to be reassured, Rick, there’s nothing gay about that, is there?
There’s nothing a touch… kind of fruity about that image.
No, I mean, I th—the ones you do avoid would be sort of “Liza Minelli Workout”…
…but, I mean, the name’s a little bit gay, isn’t it?
So I think Hel—Helen from Big Brother, you’re probably safe.
Uhm… who else, who else, I don’t know, I don’t know what else to tell you, really. Uhm…
But I know—‘cause I know you’ve got a personal trainer, I’m obviously not in that kind of stakes, the kind of stakes—I don’t have that kind of cash.
But uhm… you know, I’m obviously quite excited, what have I got to look forward to, do, do I go through a pain barrier?
My, my, my uh trainer, Pink Eric, we call him…
No I uhm… I sort of box a little bit.
But do I—what I’m saying is, do I go through a pain barrier? ‘Cause obviously I…
No no no, I stop way before that.
And I sit down… and have a beer.
You don—there’s no, there’s no point in going through pain…
So uhm if, if, if you… you know, start feeling any sort of pain or, or any uhm breathlessness, or any aches, sit down immediately.
Is it right that he’s worked out a special routine for you where you don’t have to get up?

Yeah well he actually said, I remember the fir—I, I got out my food diary, and he was looking at it, and I could see he was, he sort of feared it, he feared taking on this challenge. And, this is a true quote, at one point, he, he said, right, uhm, “Okay, cut cheese down to five times a week then,” I must’ve haggled from four.
Cheese down to five times a week.

And it, it’s sort of like… I’m my own worst enemy. ‘Cause if I cut out cheese and beer, I would just lose weight like tha—it would drop off me in a month. So what I’m doing, I’m li—just, I’m fighting it all the time, I’m… I haven’t changed my sort of eating and drinking habits. But I now work out three times a week—it is an uphill struggle, Steve.
You’re just keeping it at an even keel.
I know, well I, uh… yeah. So I can live longer to eat more cheese and beer.
Do you exercise, Karl, do you do any exercise whatsoever?
I u—, I used to go to a gym in town but it wasn’t the sort of, the hard work I do in the, you know, the stuff, it was just that—it was like, 60 quid a month.

…that’s not good. So I just go out of me way to sort of walk everywhere. D’you know what I mean, instead of jumpin’ on a bus… like a nice day like today… walk in to work. Or uh… you know, run up the stairs.
No but I, I do eat a lot of, like, crappy food so I reckon…
…I mean, what do they say, when you get to thirty it all just… you go mental, don’t ya?
Yeah they say that, play a record.
That’s the—who says tha—that’s the philosophers, isn’t it?
When you get to thirty you go mental.

Oh yeah, oh, I brought this in, you’ll love this, Steve—oh you know this, I think, I’m sure. This is a, a, a great Bowie track off “Aladdin Sane,” one of my favorite albums, and this is “Lady Grinning Soul.” It’s, it’s beautiful.
Badly Drawn Boy, “Silent Sigh,” on Xfm 104.9… I’m Ricky Gervais, you can do your own…
Oh right, okay, my name’s Stephen Merchant.
You’ve not… you’ve not lost interest, have you, Rick?
I’ve said it—I’ve said it once, I get—I was a bit bored with just saying your names.
I don’t mind saying mine ‘cause I’m sort of interested in that…
…but the other ones are sort of more of a chore, you know what I mean, there’s nothing in it for me.
Yeah, there’s no actual personal gain.
I’d rather not mention either of ya.
So if you wanna do it… from now on…
Yeah. Oookee. Ahm well, listen, uhm obviously still got plenty to come, we’ve obviously got some great music, Rick…
Uhm… oh I’ve got uhm… a bit of Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds, uhm actually an album you introduced me to, and I want to play uhm… “Into My Arms.”
And you know how beautiful that song is.

Uhm but uh I was just, obviously I was talking about this little bit of acting I was doing yesterday and ah… not wishing to be disrespectful to anyone that was involved, but there was uhm obviously some extras or supporting artists, as I believe they’re known, and, you know, all good—lovely people, really putting the effort in, doing good work and everything. But there’s this one guy I was stood next to, and you know he’s quite a tall guy, uh not as quite as tall as me but a tall guy, you know, quite a good-looking bloke or whatever, and uh… I just sat there, and it—obviously it gets quite boring because a lot of it is just hanging around and people waiting and stuff, fixing lights. I just stood next to him and he just went, “Oh…” He was looking for something to say to me obviously and he went, “Looking forward to the new Guns N’ Roses album?”
And I went, “I didn’t realize there was one on the way, actually,” and he went, “Yeah, yeah, obviously they uh… uh Slash won’t be in it, ‘cause obviously Slash is no longer with them but uh…”
“…God, yeah,” (sings) ’Sweet child o’ mine!’ One of my, one of my favorites,” just started singing some of the songs. I went…

Absolutely without irony, he was just wanting to get onto a discussion into Guns N’ Roses, but I’ll tell you this, he did not look like a rocker in any way, he looked like a bloke who would work in sort of an accounting agency’s…
…agency, yeah, or Barclays, yeah, behind the counter or something like that, very well-scrubbed, well-groomed.
Let me say there is nothing wrong with Barclays or the people who work therein.

So he goes, “Yeah, I mean I got into them with ‘Appetite for Destruction,’ the classic first album, uhm, but I even, you know, I enjoyed ‘The Spaghetti Incident’ as well. I mean I like all of them.” And I’m like, “Right, okay.” And he go—I said uhm… ah I said to him, “You ever seen them live or anything?” He went, “I have not seen them live, no, but I was lucky enough to be at Donington Monsters of Rock… and uh Slash’s Snake Pit was playing…”

…and he went, “I’d never bee—I’d never been to those live gigs before. And uh I was down in the mosh pit. Aw, man alive, I was down there and I’ll tell you this—have you been in a mosh pit?” I went, “No,” he went, “Ugh, it’s crazy down there. It’s wild. A guy threw a punch at me, I punched him, knocked him straight out… he knocked me out, so this fight went off—aw, it’s amazing, it was amazing, amazing.” I went, “Are you gonna go back?” He went, “No I won’t, because once you’ve done summat like that, you can never repeat the uhm… the experience, you know, I mean I was… there—everyone there was dressed in black. I think I was the only guy wearing a white T-shirt.”
I was like, “Okay,” I could just imagine him tucked in… as well… jeans…
That’s why, that’s why they attacked him.
Yeah. Slash himself said, “Get the tall…!”
Yeah yeah, there’s a termite in the nest!
And they just turned on him.

But, so, anyway, I go, “So, so do you go to gigs often?” He went, “No, I don’t think I’m ever gonna go to another rock gig.” And I said to him, “Why?” And he went, “I don’t think any gig I go to will be able to top the experience of seeing UB40 live.”
And I… do you know what I mean, and I… almost did what you did.
Well, that’s, that’s why I’ve never seen ‘em live, ‘cause I don’t wanna end my life.
There would be no point there.
…I thought it was a joke. I thought he was making a joke, and I was about to laugh, and I realized he was deadly serious, and I went…
I went, ”Aw, good, were they?” He went, “Absolutely blinding.”
“Uh one of the most incredible live performances I’ve ever seen.”
I imagine. Did they do songs in a sort of mock-reggae style…

And then he began to tell me which, which of his favorite—he went, “I, I don’t know if—” I said, “Have they, have they done anything recently? Put anything out?” He went, “I don’t think they’re gonna be able to top… uhm those classic albums ‘Baggariddim’…”

I remember once when I went to sign on… okay, and it—I don’t know what year it was, it must’ve been like 1979 or summat, and uh my f—I’d left school, and uh… uhm, tell me if I’m wrong, if it wasn’t out then, but this bloke was at the back with sort of like a ghetto blaster, and he was playing “One in Ten”…
…obviously making a point, he was in a dole office…
…everyone ignored him, and when it finished playing he turned it down.
And he took, he took a number and queued.
The days when they were a protest band!
When was that? What year was that, what year did it…
Someone can pinpoint that for me, phone in, 08700-800-1234. I know it had just come out.

But uhm, but what was amazing is when he said that, about UB40 being the best live experience he’s ever seen, I th—it was one of those moments where you thought, “I never thought I’d hear someone say that.”
Do you know what I mean, I don’t know why that, I can’t understand what kind of person you are. I suddenly realized at that moment there was such a chasm between us.
Is there anyone out there whose favorite band is UB40?

Aw, they, they’re a great bunch of blokes, though, you see ‘em—they, they crack me up when I see them interviewed, they’re really funny. But uhm, once you’ve heard one, that’s pretty much it, isn’t it?
I imagine. Oh I don’t know, maybe… I’m a philistine.
Maybe there’s some hidden depths to them that we don’t understand, maybe some great tracks that you could…
…point out if you’re a big fan.
Well I’m never gonna go and see ‘em because… why…
…no no! Why sort of like top your experiences…
When I, when I know I’m definitely dyin’…
You’ll summon them… to play for you.

Now again I broke the rules in the week; I met up with Karl.
I had lunch with him and we were chatting and having a cup of tee and it got on to one of Karl's favorite programmes 'The Tales of the Unexpected'.
And all i could think is that he's probably the only person in Britain where they were unexpected.
I mean to him when that that twist came at the end he'd go "Ohh gee I can't".

"So it was the tree that did it". I mean he's probably the only, and I and we were telling all these stories of horror and he liked horror stories and that and I told him this story and I don't know whether this will come across on the radio and I told him this story, it was a short, it was a horror short.
This was a film you saw was it?

Yeah yeah and um it started off there was this car crash a horrendous wreck and you saw it from the point of view of the person in the car and he was calling for his mate and he was going "Dave" and he sort of he sort of looked over and saw a body without a head that had been thrown and he goes "Oh no - Dave, Dave" and then in to the field of view came Dave his mate and looked at him with a look of horror then it sort of went black and you realised he was just a head and it had been his body.

And I said and then it came up at the end at the executions in the French revolution people experienced consciousness for you know, and he went he went "Ohh...no" he said, "You wouldn't it wouldn't be for that long", and then he went "If it was a chicken it would work".
But with two chickens in horrendous car crash.
Their own fault for driving, Rick.
It would work,"No, no" he wasn't havin' that.
"No it was too long" I think he said "How long was this film" I went about five minutes he went "No, it would work if it was a chicken".
I like the way that Karl when you relate an incident like that he is appalled and offended and annoyed with the people that made it even though he has never seen it.
I wanna see it, I think its a good idea.
But they should have thought it through a bit more.
Yeah, yeah. Do you have a favourite Tales of the Unexpected one you remember particularly that shook you up.
Yeah we were talking about the one on erm where er there's some women in prison, have you seen that one?
And she gets a bit friendly with the guy that takes the dead bodies out.
And er he says "I can get you out of here" said "What you got to do, right, you've got to er I dunno at midnight creep in".
"When you hear the bell toll that means there's been a dead body".

Yeah "There's been a dead body so what you've got to is go into like the er place where all the dead bodies are and get in the first coffin on the right and then I'll come along and carry you out and you can run away and escape".
Right so she goes "Yeah alright" so she hears the bell go.
No "I'll bury you right and then I'll come back later and dig you up" thats the point.
I does matter. Trust me Karl, it really matters.
Listen I don't know if I going to ruin this for people at home.
Can I just skip to the end I would imagine that she gets buried and he doesn't come back and she has to get buried alive.
No she, she  does it she gets into the coffin.
Right, so she gets into the coffin and er shes lying there for ages.

She can feel a bit of movement going on so obviously you know being carried somewhere, so she's thinking this is it i'm getting out, and er shes lying there for ages and thinking why isn't someone comeing along and lifting the lid off this, do know what I mean, letting me get out so she's really bored she gets a lighter out, right, lights it to have a look who she is lying on, its only the fella who said she he'd help escape.
So it is quite important that she's buried alive then isn't it, in retrospect you realise that the jeopardy is that she's buried alive and can't get out.
Yeah, makes it so much worse than just like lying in a morgue and going "actually i'm getting out of here".
Look at Karl's face having told that.
He is so pleased, his face is lit up, he's beaming like a child.
Is that your favorite horror thing ever?
Thats a good one and erm.
Let's see if anyone knows what the finger is.
When that bloke was underground wiggling his finger.
We were talking about one with er some fella who's stuck in the ground or something.
This is a motif I notice in your particular favorite ones.
This is a fella is it?
Yeah a fella, stuck. Now I seem to remember it just being his foot, to be honest, being stuck in a hole.

No he was under the ground and he got a little thing out of the pavement and he put his finger up and wiggled it, to try and catch attention, then you see a women come along and her stiletto heel just knocks his finger off.
You see, I wondering weather it was the same one as I saw.
Yeah there could be two like that couldn't there it's..

Or erm, what was that one you told me about with the er with the porn, that was a good one.
Oh, this was fantastic ,right, right there was this er.

No, no, this is important, I saw one right, I saw one on tales of the unexpectd, right, and it was um er these two gents um err what they used do to they'd look down the obituaries and they'd blackmail the um wife or the son of a dead eminent person like might be a priest or a doctor or summet and they'd go and they'd say "he bought some erotic stuff from us before he died and he owes a hundred guinnies" and all this sort of stuff and um they'd pay up becuase it was so embarrising they just didn't want, the so they'd just pay him,right.

And this one bloke said "who are these people? I'll meet with them" and he goes round there, and he goes round and they go "your father..." and he goes "my father could not have bought any erotic material from you" and they go "dedede" and he goes "he couldn't have; he's blind" ,right, and that was the twist and Karl went "so it was magasins not videos then".
Yeah, now think about it steve is that so stupid?
Well, presumably it was set in olden times.
Professional pornographers don't tend to call it, you know, erotic materials.
They tend to call it, you know, juicy jugs or whatever.
But more than that I don't understand how a video is going to be any use to a blind person either. I know that you can hear the sound, Karl.
Look at him nodding like he's caught me out.

"Your meter needs looking at?" "yes" cut. What's then? What's that? Then its just noises isn't it?

I mean that's why I save a lot of money.

Okay so this is where we just, err hijack an idea from The Sun which is White Van Man where The Sun asks umm in this instance a cabbie by the look of it. Oh no, a fruit and veg shop owner.
Ours is, ours is err ours is slightly different because The Sun sorta like umm err pick on a perfectly normal member of the public.
So that’s where we’ve got the twist.

Yeah and err they ask him about the err you know the hot potatoes and umm this week Karl my first question to you err your err just well your thoughts please on the criticism of the BBC over their coverage of the Queen Mum’s death. What d’you make of this, you aware of all the criticism that Peter Sissons asked some probing questions and he wore a burgundy tie?
I thought, that’s it yea he just had a… didn’t show respect he just had a burgundy tie on.
See that, that’s not really not showin’ respect is it?
You know, you show your respect by sort of doin’ the news on it, givin’ her a bit of coverage and showin’ what a good woman she was and whatever.
And then you move onto sport news or whatever.

I don’t like the way everything’s morbid, I was thinkin’ about it umm it’s like umm you know that way in birthday cards and that people always put funny things in them. I think you should save things like that for funerals for like funeral cards and that and try and cheer people up at times when they’re low. D’you know what I mean? Cause on your birthday you’re quite happy anyway so you don’t need someone putting a funny comment in a card I think you know when you send a card…
Whoopee cushion put on the vicars chair? What? How would you lighten up a funeral?
Just little things in the card I mean just writing stuff like “Well you know at least you’re still alive” or whatever.
So as you’re giving the eulogy…
So oh that’d be good so when so suppose someone’s husband is killed in a car crash you go round with some flowers and the little card and it says “At least you’re still alive”.
Well maybe something funnier than that.
Well maybe like if you got up to do the eulogy during a funeral just wear a pair of comedy tits?
Yeah, or those glasses that are eyes on sort of springs.
But why have…why has everyone got to be so sad about someone dying?

I agree. No what annoys me is that when you see people on television sort of members of the public and they’re crying about the Queen Mother who was sad when anyone dies, sad when anyone’s Nan dies. She was 102 and um what you know what I mean it sort of like I think they think they should cry…I don’t understand it.

Well there’s a picture in the paper today of various people who were lining the pre umm you know the funeral route yesterday and there’s a picture of a very young child maybe sort of five or six on the arms of her dad and her head bowed and it says, “A young girl there weeps for the Queen Mother” and I was looking at it and she, you can tell she’s just tired. She’s just tired and bored and it’s so transparent that she’s not crying.
Most people don’t cry when their Nan dies.
You know its sort of like…
But what is a five year old girl gonna be… why is she gonna be crying? The Queen Mum’s dead. “I can’t believe it, Teletubbies?” No the Queen Mum. “Not the Tweenies” No it’s on in a minute.

I mean I know I’m sure that you know I don’t know much about her, I don’t know if she was a great woman and obviously you know it’s always sad when someone dies but its like it’s interesting that there was a lot of tourists in that long line of people that are now queuing for hours upon hours to see her lying in state. Because it’s clearly just people who want to be part of history.
It must be gutting if you’re over from Sweden and you find out that you know the Queen Mum’s died.
You probably don’t want to carry on with you’re visit…really.

What will us three look like in the future if they’re being genetically modified, beautiful people? What will we be like? How will we be considered in society?

But I erm I don’t think it matters at the end of the day right you might look like some other kid but it’s the way that you’re brought up that will change your features and the way you are you know you’re personality.

so we don’t need to worry sort of think.
So I’m growing up on this estate and there was a, there was this woman about four houses down right, is a bit rough.

Was it like Bernard Manning in a dress?
I mean I didn’t grow up in a posh house or anything…
And I’m not saying that if you live in a bit of a rough house, you’re a bad person…
What did she look like? Tattoos? Did she look like Tony Green with a fag on?
They didn’t clean up much right.
Which, even if you’ve not got a lot of money you can still make it look nice right?
But she didn’t and a kid used to take a horse into the house.
Woah woah woah woah woah woah woah woah woah.

“Sir have you seen a horse around here?” No!
What is that from outside the saloon round the corner?
Yeah was it just tied up with a bit of…
That’s great. Did Big Jake come a’looking for it?

Where did he get a horse from? What do you mean he must have nicked it? His mum said “Where did you get that from?” He said “I bought it.” “Alright then, but keep it out the kitchen!”
I don’t want you going cattling rustling.
Where did he get a horse from Karl, and how long did he have it for? Was he leading it or riding it? “Mam open the door I cant stop!”
I can’t stop it, open the patio door as well I’ll be…
Looks like we got us a runaway!
I dunno but the thing is they couldn’t afford to buy one ‘cause they’re not cheap. So I’m just guessing, maybe that’s wrong of me. But I think…
That’s why the family didn’t have any money, they spend it on the horse!
That’s what I’m saying, I don’t think they would have bought it. So anyway…
Yeah its wise to whisper Karl, in case they’re listening.
They could be in the room next door.
Its not the buying it, it’s the keeping it as well…Oh.
So I was like in the car with me dad coming into the avenue and you used to have to drive down it to turn round.
And err, and you know sort of go back to our house.
You had the traditional method of transport, yeah.
And err, the horse was in the lounge.
And when I, when I was doing – I tried to earn myself some money once by flogging little flowers in plastic cups…
What? This is genius! He just keeps coming what do you mean you tried to flog little flowers? What do you mean?
Woah, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait a minute, let’s play a record, let’s play a record and come back to this…
Wait a minute, wait a minute…
‘Cause this story is just gonna unravel and unravel and go on for hours.
Yeah it gets deeper and deeper. Its like an onion isn’t it!
Let’s play a track Karl, we’ve created a whole world here where there’s a man living with a horse.
I mean I come from the West Country and I’ve never heard anything like that!
I just think of a big sort of like orange carpet and it’s got a re diffusion telly and its got the horse going “Oh I’m fed up in here”.
I am not taking the rubbish out again!
Right, play a record, let's have Velvet Underground. We got that lined up haven’t we?
A classic from the first album err ‘I’m Waiting for the Man’, let's come back to the horse in a second…
…little flowers in pots! What do you mean? Oh…

…classic first album, Velvet Underground and Nico, which apparently peaked at a disappointing 171 in the US charts.
And that’s obviously Lou Reed, the Velvet Underground and uh “Waiting for the Man.”
Yeah, great track. So we were talking, we were doing White Van Man… and uh we got on to uh, uhm genetically…
We got on to genetically modified babies, but somehow…
…and then Karl started to tell a story about someone with a horse, and then he got on to he was trying to make money selling flowers, just do the flowers briefly.
Well, hang on, I just wanna recap slightly, so there was a family and, who had the horse in the family?
‘Cause you lived in a ho—on an estate in Manchester.
So the, the mother, the mother was a right pig, apparently. I don’t know why that’s relevant.
Whoa whoa… you don’t need to go that far.
But what I’m trying to do is, like, make a picture for you so you understand.
What did she look like? Who did she look like?
Ahm… bit of uh, and no disrespect to her… bit like Pauline Quirke.
I knew you were gonna say that. I knew it was gonna be Pauli—did she have any tats? Did she have any tattoos?
I never got that close to her.
So, and so who had the horse? Was this her son? Or her husband?
Her daughter had stolen a horse…
Yeah. From, I don’t know where, there was a, I think there were some stables down the road or something.
And they, they kept the horse in the house with them.
They kept it in the house. But they didn’t have it for long.
Sorry, and you said you were in the house one day and you saw the horse…

No, no, what happened was I was uhm… they did this thing at school about raising money for charity. Right? For some local charity. And they said you can do anything to, to raise money, and they came out with all these ideas and I thought, “That’s good.”
But forget—well, I don’t know, I thought, “Forget the charity…”
Yeah, it’s just a good way of making money…
…so I asked me mam for, she used to have a lot of flowers around the house.
I said, “Can I just take some snippings off ‘em, and uh I’ll go and buy some plastic cups,” and uh got some soil outta the garden, planted the, the, the bits of plants in ‘em…
Did they, did you just cut, you didn’t just cut them and stick ‘em in the soil?
But I think people thought, “Well, good on him for trying.” But anyway, so I went ‘round to theirs, ‘cause I thought their house could do with a bit of color and stuff.
‘Cause it’s a bit rough. So as I went…
The horse went, “Thank God for that breakfast. They were, they, they’ve been feeding me Kitekat.”
So I got up to the door, and they opened the door, and it was one of them houses where, no carpet…
Yeah. A horse in the living room.
And the horse was walking around the living room.
And it looked quite happy and everything because… I always say that about animals…
Well, think about it, right, if you were a horse, where would you rather be: in a little wooden hut with a load of hay, or in like a house with…
…a three-piece suite and a telly and that?
No, but I was saying this the other day…
I was walking through London the other day…
…and do you know like homeless people always have dogs?
She said, “Oh, I hope, I hope she looks after it.” I said, “They’ve got—that dog is happier than most dogs.”
‘Cause people always walk past ‘em, give it a pat on the head…
…it’s with its owner all the time…
…it’s out in the open, it’s not locked up in a house…
It doesn’t eat, but other than that…
No, it does eat, though, they’re always all right. So that’s what I was saying, I think this horse… was, was doing all right for itself.
Well, not many horses have got their own house…
Yeah, so anyway, this family, who’s a bit, what, what were we talkin’ about, it was about cloning…
Right, now what I’m sayin’ is, you could say, you know, right, Steve, you could have a baby. Right?
And Ricky could see it and say, “God, I want one that looks like that.”
So you take it to the doctor’s… and I don’t know what they do, they, they inject it with something or whatever…
…and uh get a little baby and there it is, it looks the same. Now the thing is you separate, you both go off and do your own things…
Right? Now, you look at it—Steve, Stephen, this is, you look after your baby…
…you treat it well, you give it good food and that…
Right? So then it changes its looks, it goes a bit fat, you know, it gets tired easily and that sort of thing.
Why am I just feeding a baby cheese?!
Right, this, this uhm… this, this, this family who had a horse in the g—, in the, you know, in their house…
…they had a, a little baby. And me mam went ‘round and said, “You’re not gonna believe this but it’s a beautiful-looking baby.” Right?

And I was like, “Well, you know.” And uh the weird thing is it was a good-looking kid. But as time went on, they didn’t really look after it, and I’m not saying like abusin’ it, but it used to run around, it used to play out ‘til like 10 at night…
Used to chase cars! What sort of kid chases cars?!
Oh, God! Was it called Rover? Did it catch sticks?
Now, the weird thing is, it was a good-looking kid, but as time went on, and all that, like, not eating properly and its hair was all patchy…
It’s not Liam Gallagher, is it?
…and chasing cars and that, and it became an ugly kid.
And that’s, that’s what I’m saying, right, you can clone, you can clone all you like but at the end of the day, it’s how you’re brought up.
That was a hell of a point!

It……I hate it. I hate that.
I just I it’s nothing to me that.
What is its just sort of…?
…a weak shallow piece of mock comedy.

It’s sort of like, it’s sort of like it’s like a zany vicar would write from living in frume when he’s about 55 and get it published in…I hate it.
